Topic.Title: COME ON YAHOO ! ENOUGH IS ENOUGH DO SOMETHING MAYER !

Message.Msg: I guess you don't see that the 'freebies' are VERY good for the company. The best thing you can do for a tech company is to bring on the best technical talent. In order to do so, you need to offer perks that rival or beat your competitors. First, you aren't going to out-perk other Tech Giants, and you aren't going to over pay to attract the same talent as others. So, you need to at least match them and bring on a better corporate staff. The big "G" is now losing people to Yahoo! because Marissa Mayer was obviously a well respected leader in the company. In my opinion, we might even see more Google talent coming to Yahoo in the next few weeks. These perks you are complaining about will continue to attract new top-tier talent while improving the morale of existing Yahoo employees. From there, you will see new ideas and new acquisitions. That will lead to new products and more growth, which will lead to a tremendous amount of investor growth. The fact that Yahoo is bringing in top-tier talent and making these perks available to employees should highlight the company aiming to grow and not seek a buyout. I strongly believe this is the best growth potential for my investment in Yahoo, not a measly return per share on a buyout. In my opinion, you should consider the stock being under $16 as an opportunity to add to your position, if you even have one. The time to buy is now, young padwan.

Message.Title: HOW WE WILL KNOW WHEN YAHOO's CORPORATE CULTURE AND ETHICS HAVE CHANGED
Message.Msg: We will know, in no particular order, when --Yahoo has created and publicized a "hot line" for whistle blowers -The outside CPA (PricewaterhouseCoopers) has created an email address / phone number for whistle blowers. -Yahoo promotes from the ranks rather than hiring outsiders. . -Yahoo immedately deletes all message board serial spam; eliminates multiple ID's; and prosecutes the spammers. -Yahoo deletes political posts on these message boards. -Yahoo distributes real numbers about Yahoo users. -Yahoo states a clear game plan - not garbage about being a premier media company. -The Yahoo B of D makes a public statement that they work for the shareholders, not the reverse. and I'm sure you can think of a bunch more.

Topic.Title: DeCastro Leaves Google For COO Position at Yahoo!

Message.Msg: Henrique de Castro, Andrew Schulte, Patricia Moll Kriese, Anne Espiritu and Trish Crawley have all been hired by Mayer from Google. The best and brightest from Google are headed to Yahoo.

Message.Title: Yahoo CEO Mayer's hot hires from Google
Message.Msg: Henrique de Castro, Andrew Schulte, Patricia Moll Kriese, Anne Espiritu and Trish Crawley have all been hired by Mayer from Google. The best and brightest from Google are headed to Yahoo. More than just importing Google culture -- free food! free smartphones! -- to Yahoo, CEO Marissa Mayer is bringing in Google talent too. On Monday, which was Mayer's first day back since delivering a baby boy September 30, Yahoo announced the appointment of Henrique de Castro as COO. De Castro is one of several recruits whom Mayer used to work with at Google, where she spent 13 years until moving to Yahoo in July. Mayer's turnaround plan includes more hires to come, I hear. Including more Google alums, no doubt. Here are the ex-Googlers she has brought to Yahoo so far: Henrique de Castro – Chief Operating Officer: As VP of Google's worldwide Partner Business Solutions group, de Castro has overseen platforms and services for the company's publisher and commerce partners. A suave 47-year-old native of Portugal, de Castro began his career at McKinsey in London, spent two years managing sales in western Europe for Dell (DELL), and landed at Google in 2006. He's due to start at Yahoo on or before January 22. Andrew Schulte – Chief of Staff to the CEO: His most intriguing claim to fame is that he was Lady Gaga's RA at New York University. ("She was quirky, but most NYU students have their quirks.") After college, Schulte spent a year at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia . His five years at Google included various marketing gigs and a trial run as chief of staff to then-VP Mayer. Apparently, she liked him in the role. On the July day that Yahoo announced Mayer's appointment as CEO, he emailed her and told her he wanted "to catch up." It's worked out. Patricia Moll Kriese - Senior Director, Corporate Project: At Google from 2005 to 2009 and then a consultant to the web giant, Kriese came to be a close confidante to Mayer during their time in the snow together: Kriese was Mayer's deputy on multiple trips to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Kriese did a pre-Google stint at Microsoft and earned a Masters in International Economics from Johns Hopkins. Now she's one of Yahoo's culture carriers, directing Mayer's "PB&J" program to streamline process, reduce bureaucracy and remove jams inside the company. Anne Espiritu – Director of Public Relations: She was the power behind the public positioning of Mayer at Google. In PR there for seven years, Espiritu worked closely with Mayer when Mayer oversaw Google's core business, search products, and then when she moved to "local and geo," including Google Maps and Google Earth. A stylish UCal Berkeley grad, she started her career at the World Bank. Trish Crawley – Assistant to the CEO: Mayer's assistant at Google is now in the same role at Yahoo--with perhaps a little more responsibility since Mayer is a CEO with a newborn. Crawley studied Latin and Classical Studies at Wake Forest and lived in Firenze, Italy post-college, before she moved to Silicon Valley.

Topic.Title: Why shorts are ignoring the facts that Yahoo is getting $20B cash from selling Alibaba and Yahoo Japan?

Message.Msg: With the average short position lasting less than 2 days a possible windfall for Yahoo longs 2 , 4 or 8 years away isn´t much of a deterrent. And since the actual value after taxes is less than 10 billion today 20, 30 or 40 billion fantasies carry little weight.

Message.Title: Idiots
Message.Msg: Yahoo has appointed a Google executive as its next chief operating officer, paying him a hefty pay package worth about $58m over four years. I mean, it's tough work, he wouldn't do it for a penny less. Would you? I mean, that's only about $100/minute. $100, that's nothing these days.
